awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: New Frontiers in Local Error-Correction
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern communication and data storage technologies use mathematical error-correcting codes to cope with noise and unreliability of physical devices. This project will develop new error-correcting codes which support "local" algorithms for error-detection and error-correction: these give strong error-correction guarantees at ultra-fast speeds. The error-correcting codes and algorithms developed in this project will have the potential be applied to real-world data storage applications, which is very relevant to current cloud computing technology. The educational component of this project will involve the mentoring and education of junior researchers who intend to pursue their own careers in research, including women and minorities. This project will also develop courses about the important advances in the relevant topics, and make the course materials publicly available.

At the technical level, this project investigates the main problems on the existence and construction of, and algorithms and fundamental limits for local error-correcting codes. Local error-correcting codes are modern versions of error-correcting codes that support sublinear-time error detection and/or correction. They have gained increasing importance in theoretical computer science over the last few decades, both because of potential applications to communication and data storage, as well as connections to complexity theory, pseudorandomness, and cryptography. This project will develop new algebraic, probabilistic and algorithmic tools to design and reason about such codes, and local algorithms more generally. This project is motivated by several recent advances made by the investigator, such as the construction of new high rate error-correcting codes allowing, for the first time, subpolynomial-time error-correction and error-detection, and the first constructions of probabilistically checkable proofs of constant rate, checkable in sublinear time. These advances have significantly altered what is believed to be possible in this domain, and have the potential to dramatically change the way data is stored in data centers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project focused broadly on the area of coding theory and discrete mathematics, and the questions under consideration are characterized by their connections to several different fields of computer science and mathematics. One of the main aims of this project is to explore these connections, and to synthesize techniques from different areas and bring them to bear on some longstanding open problems.

Much of the work is concerned with the properties of large discrete structures, and the questions of interest in this project are relevant to the study of disordered systems that may be modeled by such structures, such as collections of interacting particles, large networks like the internet, or the human brain.

The successful execution of the project bore multiple significant results, many of which were forecasted at the inception, but some of which surfaced unexpectedly as the research progressed. Some of the prominent highlights of the project are listed as follows:

1. Antichain Codes, Bulletin of the LMS, Authors: Benjamin Gunby, Xiaoyu He, Bhargav Narayanan, Sam SpiroThis paper resolved a longstanding question at the interface of coding theory and additive combinatorics.
2. Applications of Random Algebraic Constructions to Hardness of Approximation, FOCS, Authors: Boris Bukh, Karthik C. S., Bhargav NarayananThis paper introduces some powerful machinery from probabilistic algebraic geometry to the study of hardness of approximation.
3. Improved Decoding of Folded Reed-Solomon and Multiplicity Codes, FOCS, Authors: Swastik Kopparty, Noga Ron-Zewi, Shubhangi Saraf, Mary Wootters.This paper makes progress on some basic open problems around Reed-Solomon codes.

The grant's financial support enabled the cultivation and training of two doctoral students, both of whom contributed significantly to the project's success. Furthermore, it provided the opportunity for undergraduate students to engage in summertime research via the DIMACS REU program.

The findings and novel methodologies developed in the project were extensively communicated through various talks and lectures. Moreover, this funding paved the way for the creation of new lecture courses, which were developed and subsequently imparted at Rutgers. These teaching engagements have not only spread the newfound knowledge more broadly, but have also enriched the academic community and inspired potential future explorations in the field.
